Title: CAN ENTREPRENEURSHIP EXPERIENCES CHANGE WHO YOU ARE? A THREE-WAVE LONGITUDINAL INVESTIGATION
Source title: 81st Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management 2021: Bringing the Manager Back in Management, AoM 2021
Abstract: The significant role of personality traits has been well recognized and established in organization research. Yet, heavily affected by the influential dispositional perspective (e.g., the Five-Factor Model of personality traits), this stream of research has predominantly assumed the position that observed relationships between personality traits and work variables are interpreted as personality traits cause work variables, not the other way around. This is also the case for entrepreneurship research. It has primarily interpreted the relationships between personality traits and entrepreneurship as personality traits driving individuals to become entrepreneurs. Challenging this predominant view, the current research built upon recent theory and research in personality psychology and investigated whether become an entrepreneur will change one's personality traits over time. Adopting a role-based perspective and a quasi-experimental design with three wave longitudinal data, our research demonstrated that transitioning into entrepreneurship roles from employees resulted in decreases in agreeableness and increases in neuroticism. We did not observe significant changes attributed to becoming an entrepreneur in the other three Big Five personality traits: extraversion, conscientiousness and openness. This research complements the dominant dispositional perspective in entrepreneurship research and offer practical implications for employees, entrepreneurs, and entrepreneurship training. We hope future research may integrate the selection effect of personality traits in changing entrepreneurship status and also the socialization effect of entrepreneurship experiences on altering who one is as a person (e.g., personality and identity). © AoM 2021.All right reserved.

Abstract: Key regulatory programs offer expedited processing, whereby organizations can pay to prioritize their regulatory assessment. Abstract: This research explores how a new relation of production - the shift from human to algorithms as managers on platforms - repurposes consent. Abstract: We develop a framework to answer two research questions: Does e-HRM adoption effectively enhance organizational performance? Abstract: Neuroscience is spreading differently in management fields, and little retrospective work on this spotty evolution has been made. Abstract: Drawing on signaling theory and the symbolic management perspective, we argue that a CEO's use of language that is congruent with the prevailing governance model of shareholder value maximization leads shareholders to evaluate the CEO more favorably and to reduce their activism toward the firm. Abstract: Although the “social value” concept is present in business literature for over a century, it lacks definitional consensus and sufficient theorizing.
